wjAwiTG8KAB2ZnztkfyJLw.text: If I could rate a 0 I would. My belly could not handle how poorly the service was. it took 15 minutes into our meal until a water would come and refills would only come until we asked three times. Impolite manners, did not greet or respond to our needs. Mostly the worst issue was the overcharging of food and added meals we did not order.

h2gt66RpZPLBDN3eSayVoA.text: I thought the dim sum here was very tasty. The hai gow was probably the freshest I've had. It is always a good sign when you see only Asians in an Asian restaurant, haha. That means the food is pretty authentic. My only complaint is the service. As with all Asian restaurants, the service sucks. I'm Asian so I can say this! Prices were high but obviously since it is in a casino.

0J-dRASz2SfNDiWoMGU5ZQ.text: This is our new "go to" place for Dim Sum. As many of you who read my reviews may know, I was a big supporter of Orchid Garden, for Dim Sum. They got shut down by the Health Department, for a week in January, so I decided to give KJ a try.  The Yelp secret for KJ is to do the Dim Sum for breakfast or lunch, and to arrive around 10 am, when they open . I have eaten dinner at this location, and agree with my friend Stefany V, that there is better Chinese food for dinner.   I have found the actual taste of the Dim Sum to be tastier, and fresher than Orchid Garden. I do not think they have as much variety as Orchid Garden, but I feel they serve better quality and better tasting Dim Sum.   Costwise; they are about the same as Orchid Garden.   Again, for good Dim Sum, fresh, hot, and good service, get there at 10 am, when they open.

98qbjSk2KoRiuoxjarkBtQ.text: Service and atmosphere were very good. Very clean. It's inside the Rio Casino. The dim sum carts were very quick to come. But all of the dim sum was bland and tasteless. Very disappointed. All show no go. Although the place looks great, the was way under par. I would never come again. Chang's down the street may not be fancy but their dim sum tastes a lot better.

E9eFoStbJxdfcsxXXmI-og.text: I was there at Noon for dim sum.  The place was 2/3 full of asian diners.  It was not what I would have considered a slow day.  Every steamed item that I ordered was overcooked, and the centers were warm at best.   It seems like the food was re-heated improperly, or just old. The crispy fried items were dry on top and soggy on the bottom.  Flavor was good, food temp was bad, price is low.

CBPc0G2c--Yp6NgMcivFkw.text: 3.5 stars  Decent dim sum joint, but nothing spectacular. Typical dishes you would expect from a dim sum joint. Located in the Rio.   Service was a little slow at times.. But could be due to the large room and many tables to wait on. staff was friendly.  Things I enjoyed: - Sauteed pea shoots were good (order with waiter) - Fresh egg tarts (made to order) - turnip cakes were warm and fresh, but were not served with the brown sauce

Cbd24VNA6rViTKfM9VE7Fw.text: Great authentic Chinese food! It was worth the 30 minutes wait to get in there enjoy great dim sum with reasonable price. I would suggest that people to get to the place early most of the time since there is always a bit of waiting. The shumais and the chicken feet are really good.

I5DrqiygW6LBZWAhDEpUfA.text: I thought I researched this place adequately beforehand, but I totally messed up--dim sum is only served during the day!  At night, the restaurant only serves a very small (8 items) dim sum menu.  It almost broke my heart.  Even so, we still had a great dinner.  Very authentic Chinese menu.  We loved EVERYTHING we ordered off the dim sum menu, and since each item is served with 3 to 4 pieces, we made some repeat orders of our favorite things.    Great food, attentive service, great prices!

pMCgu3sua8xMoGgai-BS-Q.text: Go to spot for dim sum! Wait can get long on the weekends (benefit of the high rank players card=minimal wait). Great prices and haven't been disappointed with the food yet. Probably best to go your first time with someone familiar with dim sum or someone who can speak Chinese as there is a bit of a language barrier. Regardless, I've tried other places around town and still come back to this place!

8MbfC0pXmmDfuOPCuMz3iQ.text: The dim sum here was delicious.  They have a special chile sauce that compliments the food well.   There is no need for soy sauce since everything is already very flavorful on its own.  All of the great dim sum places we have been to (in the US and in other countries) don't have soy sauce on the table when you are seated.  In fact, they get quite offended when you ask for soy sauce.  We will definitely be back next time we are in town.

gQy69gJAYLeKMJld5Lrf-A.text: Food was alright.   We waited for maybe 30 minutes to get seated during Christmas Eve.  The server wasn't too friendly but very prompt with our requests. I've had much better dim sum elsewhere.  The highlight of eating there was watching the servers bussing tables and aggressively pushing their carts against the dim sum cart ladies.   Chivalry does not exist there.  It was our first dim sum experience in Vegas, but we'll look elsewhere for dim sum on our next trip to Vegas now that we have a reference point to see if we'll return.

8-YRwLKOymNJJVcp1WfBLA.text: Not the best dim sum but it's still dim sum and it's Vegas! Two of my faves haha. I never knew they had an actual dim sum place in Vegas and not like the ones in the buffet. I'm excited I found this place (well my PSis did, we went for her graduation lunch). I'd def come back!

AP9v8tp4fGs02UesEocrBQ.text: Plentiful, fresh food awesome service. Worth the price. A veritable cornucopia of sea food

lsXjMKkq4bGQw3sfY5Ub2g.text: I loved the spicy salt squid, slightly different from the normal version that i order. The braised noodles were on point. Finished off with a dimsum- shui mai, yum!

w-v7zfDEX3EYBE30h1cH7w.text: Loved it! The complimentary soup and dessert were really nice.  A little salty on dishes with soy sauce.  But we had a great time there

v_6ntd_77fBmen0yMnvfbQ.text: Good food but service is bad. We got there at 10:15am, We waited for the cart lady to come by for a long time and she never came. The host had to go to the cart and get us what we wanted. When the cart lady finally came she had a bad attitude. We had to ask her what she had on the cart because she just stood there. We felt very unwelcome.

vRCwDokYYa1fX4nVeTZWcQ.text: While many of my Chinese food experiences in Las Vegas have been mediocre, I was pleasantly surprised by KJ. Their dim sum rivaled some of the places in LA and definitely beats any of the places in Las Vegas Chinatown. I haven't tried the KJ in Chinatown for dim sum but their dinner is pretty decent.    The place is clean and the waiters are respectful. I like that even though they are in a casino, they kept the traditional food carts on the floor. That's what makes dim sum, dim sum. Food comes around pretty often and they have a good selection.   You know this place is good when Chinese people are eating here and they went out of their way to come to a casino to eat.

7pCgAVCWbVUyM0TTRWyEcQ.text: Never thought I would find decent dim sum and cantonese food at a Las Vegas hotel/casino but, we did. Even my in-laws liked the food here and that says a lot. We are all from or eat regularly at Chinese restaurants in the San Gabriel Valley so we know what authentic Chinese food taste like.   The place looks pretty nice and the service was pretty good. Wasn't hard to get the attention of the wait staff. The dim sum was pretty decent. The only problem we had with it was that it wasn't piping hot like we would find at NBC in Monterey Park. We also had dinner here as it was about 50 degrees outside with a bracing wind and didn't want to take the in-laws outside. We were pretty satisfied with the dinner too. The pork chop with spicy salt was good as I had at any Sam Woo and the sauteed pea shoots were very tender and delicious.   The prices were of course higher than anything in the San Gabriel valley but, they weren't as bad as I thought they would be. However, it you want a bargain, just drive a couple blocks north to Spring Mountain Rd. and try one of the many asian restaurants there.

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Good dim sum but, we wish it was hotter.
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States

iYoEOHI4ZsJa2k-ckbgqEw.text: on a day like mothers day to come out and enjoy some dim sum with a group of people is something you don't want to do for future reference well at least here.. first off the people that were in the front aren't organized and the food was just bleh.. we eat dim sum alot and have eaten at a KJ establishment before so for them it was definitely just a disappointment from the start. save yourself some money and go to another dim sum place because i think this place is overpriced and the food isnt that good anyway. i will not be back unless we are forced to eat here with family. Sorry but ill go to Orchids Garden before i eat dim sum here again.

Jm0MujIEx86-KjAyqdGvuw.text: Definitely hits the spot but not the most amazing dim sum that I've ever had.  The restaurant is HUGE. Tons of tables so there was no wait.  They also actually have carts which is nice, definitely a rare sight these days.  Xiao long bao: Medium skin, a little bit of soup and you get three in little individual tins. The tins are fun because they keep the soup in   Ha/Sha chang fun: Woaaahh tons of the rice noodle wrapping and little shrimp but otherwise pretty good  Shumai: *two thumbs up*  Dan tat: We got it fresh...but definitely less egg yolk than other places. I like my dan tat really yellow otherwise they taste more like cream than anything  They also have kai lan, shi fan etc etc. Fairly authentic but I do feel as if there are some short cuts made ingredients wise. Definitely wouldnt complain to come back again but wouldn't put it on my must-visit list either  Staff is nice and no complains there either :)

wLaTxI8ALr6Ro_1nvAmOmw.text: If you're ever in Vegas I totally recommend this restaurant. They have excellent authentic Chinese food. The food portions are huge and the prices are very reasonable. The service is fast and efficient. Very convenient to the exit of the Rio. Plus the restaurant has late hours too!

9iKXivYWkgyQ2SB2xLj2ag.text: A medium sized place for a Chinese Dim Sum Restaurant.  This place is inside the Rio casino across from the Buffet.  Food wasn't bad for this area.  Some waiters can speak Cantonese and some only understands Cantonese.

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. dim sum

-60Y5GgxOMdNFtWEeU7mTQ.text: Very delicious, and service is very good. I came here at midnight when we didn't need to wait. In the morning there are a lot of customers waiting outside.

5gNdn8AKYJUDXLJ5Ow4ulw.text: We were in Vegas a couple of weeks ago for a Seminar and wanted to try some authentic chinese Food. We tried out KJ Dim Sum at the Las Vegas Rio Resort and boy was that an awesome Brunch.  Everything was so delicious and well prepared with a super nice staff. Go try this place, you will love it. When the Bill came I could not believe how inexpensive it was for that quality of Food.  We'll be back for more next time when we are in Vegas.

ERIIi6b6Q6snrhVBuIEhaA.text: Ok dim sum. Not so many choices. Someone recommended this place is one of the best dim sum but I have had better back in Hawaii. Disappointed. Prob never come back.

Yvnj8dxq_1Pc0zRir3dqQw.text: Located inside the Rio casino across from the buffet. Clean and spacious with quick seating and okay to good service. Food has always been good and served quick.   Only problem is they don't reward the local discount even with the approved temporary stamp on my rewards card. Rewards will verify with utility bills to be sure you're local. The stamp is good for any Harrahs location that offers the discount, besides this place. They could easily verify by calling rewards but instead were very rude and didn't even try to listen to me.   They have lost my business. I've talked dozens of people into going across the street to ping pang pong instead. If located inside the casino you should respect the casinos rules and customers.

MEonXvMUqqSWRUKEpQBn2Q.text: Possibly the best dim sum in Vegas. I pleasantly surprised how good they are. The polo char siew bun is amazing. My favorite dim sum item.  They're other items are great too. The purple dumplings are my next favorite. Don't remember what they're called but you have to train them.  Everything is good your can't go wrong. Will RTE!

BDMjUSnYQDk2Pn42blKmsw.text: Food was ok,service is bad,cant expect service from Chinese restaurant,need improvement.

MomvUNLTukyLRw-quFmJhg.text: Outstanding authentic Chinese cuisine. Very good!  Definitely going back!  Mongolian beef was delicious!

kJ4nfenoGKlB67q3W-b9Ig.text: This is our fifth time here... We frequent this place maybe every other month. Located inside the Rio across from the Carnival Buffet, this place is good for late night Chinese food eats as they are open till 2:00am!   No HIS/HER orders here. More of a "community" type meal where you share orders.   1.) We always start with the CRAB MEAT & FISH MAW soup. This can serve about 7 people (small bowl) but honestly I can never have just one! Not too salty with a porridge type texture. A must try! (8/10)  2.) A hidden gem that's not on the menu, you have to ask for the FRENCH BEEF. It is not a large dish, but the meat is seriously cooked and seasoned to utter perfection! Another must try. (10/10)  3.) We also get the crispy PAN FRIED NOODLES, which is honestly more of his favorite, are crispy noodles that soften with the sauce it is topped with -- comes with vegetables, shrimp, scallops and fish. This is his go-to... He swears by it! (9/10)  4.) To add some veggies into the mix, you can't go wrong with CHINESE BROCOLLI WITH OYSTER SAUCE. A generous amount of the steamed, leafy stalks with a side of the brown sauce (a little goes a long way!) (9/10)  5.) I personally am not a big fan of the SALT & PEPPER PORK CHOPS, but it's something he always orders too. A tad oily for my taste and honestly too salty. I'm not a big fan of pork or super oily and salty foods, so this is just not for me. (3/10)  6.) Probably one of my newest favorites is the BEEF CHOW FUN. Wide rice noodles with tender stir-fried beef with bean sprouts & onions... So savory. I can eat just one order and nothing else, it's that good! (10/10)  7.) I'm a big fan of fried rice, and I must say this place has amazing DRY SCALLOP FRIED RICE. It's not too oily and is not too salty... A good portion and pairs well with anything you order! (9/10)

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crab meat fried rice.
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pan fried noodles with combination seafood.
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef.

GzXicZQRJK_BzwQ8R02quQ.text: We came here because Ping Pang Pong was way too busy and to our delight there was no wait at KJ. The restaurant is big and is very clean! It's just 1 big open floor... The servers must get their cardio in when it's super busy.   We ordered all of our standard dim sum items and to be quite honest nothing stood out. Nothing was amazing compared to any other local dim sum place and they also didn't have a couple things that we typically get elsewhere. However, they did have some interesting blue colored seafood dumplings and black squid ink dumplings. The service was fast but prices seemed to be a little bit higher since its in a casino? ...we probably won't be back unless we happen to be in the neighborhood.   HOT TIP: Park in the parking lot or the parking garage closest to the corner of Valley View and Flamingo so that you can directly walk to the restaurant instead of walking through the casino~

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States

RoybwhmPuBBCNL7cAIOxvg.text: This is as good as it gets in Las Vegas for good dim sum. Everything ordered was good. The juice dumplings were a bit below average, and my favorite radish cakes were cold from being left out. Besides that, the seafood dumplings were my favorite (which has a clear exterior, and had a medley of seafood inside). I've heard that Ping Pang Pong is the other place that's also really good.   Service was quick, and they went out of their way to go get dishes that they had stopped serving. Awesome! After ordering a ton of items in a group of 5, it came out to $25/pp and we were stuffed with a decent amount of leftovers for a whole meal.   If I'm craving dim sum in the future, it'd be a close call between here and Dim Sum Cafe.

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. All kinds of dim sum.

AJ5hPsbOiSJgbS1ZPle_dg.text: Was mad suspect when I found this place was located in the Rio, but it delivers authentic dim sum. Has that grimy authentic dim sum feel with servers that don't speak English very well, but is nicer/cleaner than your typical strip joint Chinese place.The pricing was also surprisingly reasonable as well. Dishes were all pretty good, no complaints. Would come back to get my dim sum fix.   Bonus you get to see white people awkwardly try it for the first time

SCT-H7XT7RbIKGO6GzsWNw.text: I came for the dim sum and the food was only okay.  Visiting from a smaller city, I would've expected this place to have better dim sum than my hometown, but it was on par. The pros of this place was that the price of some of the dishes were cheaper ($3 for some certain dishes.. now if only the conversion rate was in my favour), and the crazily efficient service of all the cart ladies. We were a party of 6 and were seated right away (less than half of the restaurant was filled up), as we had arrived around 11am, which is a bit earlier than the rush. Once we sat down, the cart ladies were quick to come over one right after another to show us their available selections. I have never been to a dim sum restaurant where we got all the dishes we want within minutes. I'm so used to always eyeing carts for everyone's favourite dishes, and even asking the servers for specific dishes. We barely had time to start eating the dishes that were already in front of us, when the cart ladies made their way back to us again. We joked that they might have been on commission, as they were very persistent. We were in and out in less than an hour, which was faster than the shake shack line we were in the night prior.  I would recommend if you're looking for a quick meal, but don't expect a mind blowing meal.

5Ivjksd8_fwpll0ffiI-Bw.text: Too few dim sum carts, waited forever and had hardly any food. Gave up and left. Bad service too. All the waiter did was come by and take our unused chair for another table. What we did eat was just blah. Dried and cold fried shrimp wontons and crab balls.

1zaAZCD_ryoPdDKJKZFZMg.text: I dined in this place with a not knowing what to expect. The dim-sum back home is really good and I didn't know whether this place would fair as well. Ive read the reviews and because I was craving chines street food, I gave this place a try. First, the service was slow. The restaurant wasn't full so we expected faster service to get our water and hot tea to us. But, that didn't happen.  The price of the meal was cheap, that's expected for dim-sum restaurants. Once the carts started to roll by we ordered shumai, beef and pork rib tips, shrimp dim-sum, and shrimp balls. None of them, left a lasting positive taste in our mouths. They were just okay.

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork shumai, pork rib tips, shrimp shumai, and sesame balls

jV8gLg_24CJ0MrqvK7w6Ww.text: Honestly not sure why this place doesn't get higher ratings. We stayed at the Rio so this was conveniently placed right along our trek to the parking lot.  Ease of getting there already earns 2 stars! And BC free parking -who doesn't like free parking on the strip? Food also tasted hot. It is very important to me that the food is piping steaming hot bc that is the only way to truly taste the wonderful flavors and fully savor each and every bite! Now the reason I'm saying this is bc our friends kept telling us to visit Ping Pang Pong (what an interesting name by the way...), but why did nobody tell me that our food was going to come out cold? Every. single. dish. The hottest thing might have been the outside of a bun but the inside was cold (Egg Yolk bun) yo, last time I checked, the filling is supposed to be pretty warm/hot! Ok why is this turning into a rant about PPP. Sorry back to you- as I was saying. The service and quick and the food is great. The end.

5joLkQemZABwsiinM8-abg.text: This place gets crowded on weekends, but we were lucky enough to walk in about 10 minutes before the dim sum rush.  We were seated quickly and although it took a little longer than we would have liked to get drinks and dim sum service started, once the carts started coming around the food was plentiful and good.  We ordered a number of items and although not the best dim sum I've ever had, it was good and everyone in my party left satisfied.   The decor and restaurant setup is lovely and there is plenty of space to accommodate many large parties, which is the best way to enjoy dim sum. The more is definitely the merrier here.

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States

_XM_xBSmtQhVa4s2kZqNuA.text: tldr  Extremely fast, lazy Susan's, plentiful menu  Get: -Cantonese style beef (off menu) -pan fried noodles -beef chow fun -crab maw soup -Chinese broccoli

VP6tH2DBV2sX5MBpkZLpQQ.text: I might not be Chinese but have eaten dim sum all over town for over 30 years!  I am not a tourist or first time eating dim sum. But  it seemed like the dim sum cart would go around to every table a 2 or 3 times before even attempting to come by our table. But since they seated us right next the kitchen door, you would think they would see some 6'5" guy frantically waving his arms for the cart to stop and come by to no avail. When the always half full cart finally came by I asked for fried calamari.  Much to my surprise they did have that batter fried beauty which is one of  my dim sum favorites.  Not my surprise it was cold and and dry.  As they were quickly walking away I requested another calamari. After 3 people coming to my table asking why I am sending the cold dry calamari back they finally agreed.  Promptly 2 minutes later piping hot calamari was delivered. WOW I thought now what good service. Until I looked down and it was the same plate, with the same little soy sauce and the same calamari. Now not only was it the same plate of old cold and dry calamari just microwaved. After trying to chew these usually tender morsels, I might need to go dentist to sharpen what's left of my teeth after trying to chew these from now unrecognizable pieces of battered rubber. Asking why they would just try to reheat my old calamari . Which is now better suited for retreading my tires. She responded this is all there is. I said really it's 11:45 on a Sunday morning and your out already.  After seeing many more carts coming out with what looked like fresh calamari on it. I guess they just thought no more just for me! I again asked if the carts could come by. Much to my amazement they said I could just asked what I wanted they would just bring it to me.  Asking for some more of the basics, shrimp balls stuffed wonton with fish cake etc. all hand delivered all old and cold!!! None was taken from the outgoing carts but out from the adjacent kitchen doors.  Wondering why if it's coming right out of the kitchen how it would be so dry and cold. Our friends of 40 years, whom have owned several restaurants who were dining with us said, it was it might be the SMARTER for me not to order anymore! I may say this might have been the worst dim sum out of hundreds of times I've ever eaten dim sum over 30 years. The only thing worse than the food was what I felt as a non-Asian just trying to eat. FIRST and LAST time there! If this is the standard customer service or quality of food I say PASS! Any worse service they could close for the day for sensitivity training!!!

KFMIg96OpXyDvYONhMUCxw.text: KJ Dim Sum is usually our go to spot when we have friends or family in town or when we just crave dim sum. It was a dim sum craving kind of day and my kids love the shrimp dumplings.  We came in late at 2:30pm before dim sum ends at 3pm. I usually like coming in as soon as they open so we get fresh made dim sum and not the end of the day dim sum. But as I mentioned before, today was a last minute dim sum craving day. The place was not busy and we sat down right away. We ordered shrimp dumplings, pork shu mai, shrimp rolls and beef chow fun. Everything was good. Then we got the beef chow fun, there was lots of onions, green onions and bean sprouts but minimal noodles and beef. All I tasted were the veggies. No, seriously!!! I have gotten in the past and it's perfect. Not sure if they started getting stingy with the noodles and beef part. Since I was paying $15 for the beef chow fun, I said something to the server and he basically said, "This is how we make it. If you want another one, you can order another one." Wow. Not friendly and not helpful. I asked for a manager. The manager was more accommodating and had them make another dish for me to go. That was nice. When I got home, I looked in the to go dish and problem not really solved. Still so much veggies and bit more beef and noodles. All I have to say is I won't be ordering this dish here any longer. Not worth it.   Other than that experience, we love KJ Dim Sum and will continue to come here for dim sum only.

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef Chow Fun. Take 2. The dish do over. Still so much veggies and not enough beef and noodles for $15!!!
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The dim sum cart. Dim sum is consistently good here and it&#39;s our go to spot for out of town guests.
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef Chow Fun. Take 1. Too much onions, green onions and bean sprouts. That&#39;s all I tasted.

cqqoyumBPFPVwmj56jmNhA.text: Came here since we were at the Rio. I was surprisingly pleased with the decent quality of the dim sum though not as good and little pricier than what you can get from San Gabriel Valley in LA. BUT, I prefer this over a buffet. It was a good option in the hotel. They charge $1pp for tea. Enjoyed the egg tarts (flaky crust, good flavor), fresh crunchy Chinese broccoli w oyster sauce, shrimp rice noodles, dumpling w shrimp and veggies, sweet pork bun (tasted wine) Just OK- shu mai.

VkOkGoDlIgkS-KmDZCwBog.text: Had a very pleasant experience at this restaurant. Its nicely decorated, lots of red. We got there at 5pm on a Saturday and were seated right away. Seems like the rush begins at 6pm. The staff there are friendly and constantly checks on us through out the meal. Making sure our tea was filled with hot water, or even the soda and water are topped off. Also offered extra sauce to our dishes we ordered if we like. We started with the egg flower soup. Served nice and hot. Then the main dishes came out after we finished the soup. Braised yee noodles, Peking style pork chops, and sweet and sour fish fillets. All the dishes were served hot from the kitchen. Nice flavors and really tasty. If you want rice, need to order. As we finished up and getting ready to leave, the staff still comes by to check on us, even as the restaurant was filling up and getting busy. Definitely will be coming back.

xZ5dSC5cOTuLgZ7GWpwWog.text: We were looking for a quick dinner before the Penn & Teller show in Vegas. We enjoy Chinese food and thought it would be a good fit, being the performance was in the Rio. I can't say it is a 4 but a 3 1/2, yes. The restaurant wasn't busy or crowed and thought we would be in and out, in no time. Our server was very friendly and helpful in navigating us through the menu. The food was prepared quickly as we had hoped. Chicken and Broccoli is my go to, when I am not sure about the menu. It was good, not great, it lacked flavor and taste. The meal was served hot. The price of our dinners were very reasonable. I wouldn't say I would return, but I am not going to say it's a place you shouldn't try.

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken &amp; Broccoli
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu of KJ Dim Sum &amp; Seafood Chinese Restaurant

IM_pKv4CHVYNTcKjTBmkMg.text: Me and buddy came for dinner, we order quite a few dishes, and none of them was good......especially the beef tasted horrible, like bloody or some other kind of smell......would not ever come back for that

3XIK_bHCSXkA9iGjZCWSSw.text: A very good dim sum. But a few items here and there were down right inedible, so you'll have to pick and choose with a discerning eye.   My breakdown: 2 stars for food 1 star for dim sum service 1 star for chili sauce  Yes, 1 full star just for their own homemade condiment. That's how dang good that chili sauce was. Pretty much order anything that can be dipped into that sauce ... Your dim sum will magically taste better.   Don't believe me?  I even took a picture. In fact, it was the only picture I took!  And it is also the only reason I am writing this review.   KJ's chili sauce. Everything else is for dipping only.

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The Angelina Jolie of chili sauces - spicy, good heat and a hidden undertone of sweetness at its core.

sVMVxBZeRM0ZaCIj3EowsQ.text: Best yum cha in Vegas!!!! This review is only for brunch lunch. Piping hot and fresh, good flavors, they had my favorites but u do have to order the steamed egg yolk buns which are yellow colored on the outside too unlike the Lai Wong baos. Really good lo Mai gais sticky rice in lotus leaf too bc they actually have the salted duck egg unlike a lot of other cheaper dim sum places. All the customers were Chinese mostly speaking Cantonese too so we know where it's at. My favorite steamed bean curd roll was so hot it nearly burned my tongue as u bite into it with good light perfect sauce. Mmmmmm. They didn't have the taro Mochi or the goji berry jello though nor the matcha baked buns so darn. Taro buns were just ok for me, I guess I prefer them in Mochi or savory dishes. With a lot of really solid dishes here, I may have to come back to eat the e-fu noodles or even something different like shanghai chow mein. I was too full to order the Jia Leung Chinese donut wrapped in rice noodle with hoisin and regular sauce since I had to order another of the egg yolk buns bc they were so good and I ate 4 out of 6 between my husband and I...pig.... Very happy with the food and will come back again hopefully with more people so I can order and try more dishes!!

MjNvfYYueW_hBCQYyKxBsA.text: Lunch Dim Sum Review ...  Bottom Line: Mediocre dim sum. Disappointing.  Service: Service was okay, but nothing special ... and somewhat slow.  Food:  Rice Porridge(Congee) - Watery, skimpy on the extras (thousand-year-old egg, green onion, etc.).  Steamed Pork Bun (Char Siu Bao) - Okay, but nothing special.  Steamed Pork Spareribs in Black Bean Sauce - Okay, but again nothign special, very fatty.  Chicken Feet - Mediocre, lacking in flavor, possibly underseasoned.  Rice Wrapped in Bamboo Leaves (Zong Zi) - Very mediocre, somewhat bland and mushy.  Fried Shrimp Ball - Mediocre, lacking in flavor, very dense, and not crispy.  Turnip Cake (Luo Bo Gao) - Cold ... blah.  Sesame Ball - Cold, with bland filling.

vav4AZL3Ug9y6-7eDovg8g.text: 3.5 stars.  Customer service is great (fast & courteous).  Waiter kept my water refilled the entire time.   Food is okay - I find it a bit bland on some of the dim sum.  My friends loved it.  It's a good place to go to get the dim sum craving.  I haven't been to the other dim sum places in LV so I can't say how it compares.  We had about 16 dishes and totaled with tips was around $78.    The dim sum with the buttery sweet filling is delicious.  Get it while it is fresh out.

MeHQe9wRvFSTfaYxPykXOQ.text: I had high expectations for this place bc it was highly recommended &  took a trip to eat here. Dont ha e high expectations! I thought the food was good,  nothing amazing like i cant get anywhere else. But i was pretty disappointed in the amount of dishes they provided.  I get it,  its a tuesday. Maybe they have better food on the weekends,  u tell me. And they had maybe 5 carts of different things going around,  3 being tofu & congee & chinese broccoli. We got 6 dishes off of the first cart. Thinking theres gonna be more,  there wasnt. What we got was pretty much their staple. And the restaurants was 1/2-3/4 full,  but only have one cart of each going around is a bit slow to me.. But whatever idc. Just disappointed in the fact that there wasnt as much options. I can get alot more dishes at other dimsum spot ive tried in the midwest. And i had to ask for certain dishes because it wasn't on the cart (even tho i saw them bring it to other requesters).  My favorite thing there is probably the egg tarts. So much flavor abd u can taste the custard in it,  alot of places dont hit that right spot for it.  Their dessert is probably what i would come back for if im really craving it.  Service is bad,  which i knew coming in, no expectations there. Food is good but not that many options,  maybe go on the weekends for more options. But was disappointed.

TD_0uFFIu_84bSNqkWqTWQ.text: Very good Chinese food, not too Americanized. Attentive service, solid dim sum, and a nice, mostly quiet atmosphere-- a nice mini-reprieve from the hustle and bustle of the casino floor.

ZQ3AZK0fIrHK4OGNgxStsg.text: The food was tasty & much fresher than I expected. I was also surprised to see that our party of 6 could be seated right away considering we were there on a holiday weekend during peak dinner hours.  However, what really bothered me was how scatter brained the wait staff was. The table next to us was waiting most of their meal for their order of fried rice to come out. So much so that when we got our order, they thought that it was their order (so did we...and even the waiter wasn't sure so he had to go back and check). We also asked for our sweet & sour soup to come out first (as it should) and yet it came out 2nd and only after we asked our waitress where it was.   This just seemed to be the place's MO. On several occasions we saw servers come up to our & others' tables with food in their hand not sure if they were to put them down or bring them to a different table.   If the are able to straighten this out, this restaurant would be a great place to check out while at the Rio. However, until then, if I want some good Chinese food, I'll just drive down the street a bit & visit Vegas' Chinatown.

BxNZWmDJw5S3YDDYUEav6A.text: Service: for las vegas standard this chinese restaurant has not stepped up...so staborn on their ways that same service you get at typical chinese restaurant exists here...sounds stereotypical? maybe but this under par service is not Las Vegas experience.  Food: i have eaten at lots of dim sum places from LA, San Francisco, Hong Kong, Singapore, and Jasmin at the Belagio...the taste of food in this restaurant is considered street quality...some street foof in asia taste better.  If you want better quality just eat at chinatown...at least there your expectations for service and food quality will be at same level you would expect from familiar chinese restaurant where ever you come from...

NPv5vKu5wwj_Npwk3RlTKQ.text: Very busy place in Rio Casino & Resort. Nice & clean dinning area, good Chinese restaurant ambient. Dim sum selections are good. Service is pretty good & fast, dinner menu has good selections as well. Recommend to try.

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Egg Custard Pie... Yummy
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Steamed Shrimp dumpling
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States

6woSAy83-ME96QJ6E_KrfA.text: Before heading off our separate ways home, my friends and I decided to have some breakfast. After eating at too many buffets over the weekend, we went with a controlled portion breakfast.  My friend suggested that we eat at his favorite dim sum spot. Apparently, when we got here, he wasn't the only one who thought  this was his favorite dim sum spot in Vegas. Our party consisted of 11 (10 adults and 1 toddler). We were early enough to get seated right away. This place reminded of some dim sum spots back in the Bay Area, but on a smaller scale. Waiters still pushed carts from table to table up selling items we wanted or to pass up. Our table came to order the following dishes:  - Pork siu mai  - Calamari - Chinese broccoli - Pan fried noodles with chicken - BBQ pork bun - Rice noodle wrapped with beef - Roast duck   All these items were very tasty. The rice noodle wrapped with beef, calamari, and the pan fried noodles with chicken were my personal favorites. The rice noodle dish was something new to me, but reminded me of my love for beef chow fun. The pan fried noodles were semi-crispy but soft and paired well with the tender chicken.  Service was not the greatest. It gets busy to a point where your table maybe forgotten. One of the waitresses spilled water on my friend and apologized.   Overall experience: 3.5 stars

nqBDLnHHoRe6ZorgR41zMQ.text: Very good, and don't be scared that because it is located in the RIO Casino that would be expensive, because it is not.   Parking HINT,  park on the west side.   It is located across from the Carnival World Buffet.  Staff and service is excellent.   Very clean too.

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States

xM80rVrhBkH70GQj-c4RcA.text: Every time I go to vegas to visit my mom, it always ends with dinner at the other KJ location.  When I came to visit again and only had time for lunch, I was surprised when she asked me to meet her at the KJ located in the Rio for dim sum.  Surprisingly, the Dim Sum here was not bad. A bit pricey, but decent.  They have all the regular selections: hai gow, shu mai, lotus wraps, shrimp noodle, chicken feet, spareribs etc.  The portion sizes were comparable to most dim sum places and the ladies pushing the carts came by frequently.  It's definitely not up to par to the dim sum in LA/SGV or SF...but for vegas, I have nothing to complain about.  With a table of 9 people, the bill came out to be a little over $100 and we were all stuffed.  I only wish that they had a bigger selection than the usual and standard fare. I guess they covered all the basics.   Decent food. Good service. Comparable prices. Nice alternative to Pho.

Ev4bJkOMcq0wpfrsVCLQzQ.text: There wasn't a lot of choices here in the Rio. We decided to take a chance and we were pleasantly surprised.

MPc0-4ZQbdk6An7s7vpj7A.text: Good food, but the dinner prices are a bit over the top. I strongly recommend going during lunch, you can't really beat it, but the prices at dinner are hard to justify.  I'll be a lunch regular, but I'll never be back for a dinner

91DUhH7sKe2ekRyNjZMijw.text: For a little over $40, Earl and I enjoyed a delicious dim sum lunch, and some food leftover for breakfast the next day.  The servers were attentive, and the cart ladies were not pushy and remembered our turnip cake order.  We got there at 11:50ish on a Sunday, and we only waited for 10 mins before we got our table.  Within 10 minutes later, there was an ocean of people that came in and had to wait.   We ordered all of our usual items and they were very good.  KJ will be our go to when we want some delicious dim sum.

t-6WEtW9OLw0YKUhV4tkow.text: WOW!  I don't even know  where  to start.  I think I know...rude customer service all the way.  My family  and I where going to eat at the buffet right across this Chinese restaurant.  The buffet had a long line and we did  not wanted to wait that long so we decided  to try this restaurant.  The second  we walked in, we felt uncomfortable and not welcome at all.  I did not know why may be because is an open concept the makes you feel like you are in a banquet hall.  Who knows.  We sat down, they did greet us, all they ask...something  to drink? Very rude and short.  How about hi how are you? Can I offer you something  to drink? Would you like some  tea? No! Nothing we barely  got water.   Well then we got our food.  Surprisingly this is why I gave them 2 stars because  the food was yummy  We had to ask for the check and the girls kept looking  at the card as if it was fake.    The whole  time we just wanted to eat fast and get out of there ASAP.   Their customer service is selective and they do not treat everyone with the same manner.  Ironically, we were ready to drop a lot of money for our dinner, but instead we ordered very minimum and left them not tip.  Your tip needs to be earned  based and your customer service.

-pUpM7GuBYp_NopqEmssVQ.text: A friend who owns one of the best Chinese Resteraunt in SoCal told me that this is the best dim sum in Las Vegas. Unfortunately he did not tell me that the dim sum standards in  Las Vegas were so low.   I give them a 4 for getting me a place to sit quickly however after that the points go down quickly. It was over 5 minutes before a waitress came by and asked if I wanted something to drink.   The carts though plentiful only came by one out of four times.  The overall selection was somewhat limited and the flavors (or lack of) were not even close to the levels that got me to love dim sum. The chicken feet were undercooked and no flavor. The ribs were more fat then meat and again flavor lacking.  The shrimp were just average.   My recommendation is to go down to Spring Mountain Rd and try another type of Asian food which has much better flavors. There are a lot there with much higher quality, fetter taste and good prices.  So eat well Vegas but just by here.   T

cglVPUsxcGhvTfO_BDURMA.text: First time here... it was ok, but I think Ping Pang Pong is better.  We ordered our usual items.  But best of all was the service... everyone was super friendly!  Atmosphere was nice.  Har gow and siu mai was on the smaller side- those were 3.18 each.  Didn't care for the green looking skin that had seafood inside... it was too fishy tasting.  Steamed pork buns were decent but a bit doughy.  That one was considered small and in the $2 range.

7kaSX2pa0NA7zNDP7jOWug.text: My first time having dim sum and this place was definitely pretty good. I wish each server had less entrees on the cart so the food would have been hot. Everything was pretty cold. I really liked the shrimp dumplings and egg custard cake things. The service was just OK.

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States

6g-cHaap7tu96WzNnwxYZg.text: I have wanted to try this place for so long and was happy I finally got an opportunity on my last trip. Located on the first floor of the Rio, KJ is a go to spot for Dim Sum. First clue, it is PACKED with people waiting for a table. Fresh Dim Sum offerings travel through the dining room on carts by a crew of staff. If you have a special request or item you are looking for, just ask and the servers spring into action to find it for you. Our drinks never went empty and the quality dim sum for the price was shocking! I pay double for dim sum in San Francisco. Couple of tips., you can gain entrance to KJ by the parking lot of the RIO and avoid walking through the casino. It is open 24 hours on Saturday nights so you can always get your fix. And they do take out orders!!! If you want a quick bite late at night, swing by grab some yummy steamed delights and head on out. I would definitely recommend it and will be back for more pork buns! YUMMO!

nTCPhyAQFL0qqD78ngJlhw.text: I walked in excited to get take out Dim Sum after a long day of business. Service was prompt but I was immediately disappointed to find out that they only serve Dim Sum at lunch. Really? For a place with Dim Sum in the name, that advertises hours of 10 am- 2 am you would think they served Dim Sum all day.  Settled for the chinese food instead, Chow Fun, Mongolian Beef and Sweet N Sour Pork (figured I could spice it up with chili paste and make it taste similar to Szechuan which I prefer).got back to my room only to discover they gave me fried rice instead of Chow Fun, but I was too tired to go back. Not that it would have mattered because it was all so bland. Even the pork! I mean, how hard is it to make Sweet n Sour Pork. The fried rice was nothing but white rice layered with raw cabbage, julienned white onions and beef cubes. No sesame oil, no soy, no carrots, no flavor. Even the chili paste was bland. If this is the top in Vegas I'd hate to see what the rest are like.

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bland fried rice.

HaRALN88alBZYrgsiJjfwA.text: Yummmmmmm DishCity and Dimsum. Are among the two most awesome Dim Sum Houses in Las Vegas. Don't miss the Dim Sum Cart Experience 10-3pm everyday. KJ Dim Sum at Rio and Amazing Ping Pang Pong at Gold Coast Casino across the street... Are The Bomb!!!!!!!!!!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Lines waiting to get table seat call order numbers
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Packed all seats
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Being Asian is so Cool.  Culture is a Wonderment

02NsmZUsvvThYIvAfYgWAg.text: The Skinny: okay dim sum, okay prices (3), service: IMHO, it's okay, comfortable seating (3) value: it's not bad for dim sum(3).  We don't really eat dim sum in Las Vegas. The reason is that the dim sum here ain't that good in town. Considering the number of Chinese tourists, you'd expect things to be a lot better than they are. That being said, if someone has a hankering for dim sum, we generally come here for the more comfortable seating arrangements and the slight edge it has on the food.  Don't get me wrong, it's nothing really special. I'll be the first to admit that the meatballs have been mixed with too much cornstarch. The cheung fun has way too much rice noodle compared to the meat filling. All the meat items kind of taste the same. Oh and the XLB come in little foil cups which = not good in my books - and the fact that they serve XLB in the first place but that's another story. The pinepple bun/runny egg yolk buns often leak too and they look exactly (suspiciously) the same as the ones that you get @ East Ocean. Hmmmm....  I'll be the first to admit though, their sweet tofu is a guilty pleasure and I usually get an order of this because I'm a sucker for fresh sweet tofu.  Shove all that aside and consider where that we are in the dim sum desert here in Las Vegas. All things considered, this place gets a 3-starred review - it's okay for what it is, it's reasonably priced and it's more comfortable than other establishments.

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States

u4YgSVlF2PRa5Mb1_JKYow.text: Xiao Long Bao was definitely not Xiao Long Bao. Shit was definitely from a microwaveable packet. The only good item they have is the congee.

3LvVQLUWWnkKC7NO1sJoDw.text: I have to say this was excellent and service was amazing.  Only issue, and it is minor, is that the lighting is just a bit too bright, especially for an evening meal.  But the food and service were very good!!!

UfV7Ffq6A19rLzmkv6Twhg.text: My new go-to dim sum joint!  Depending on what time you go on the weekends, there might be a wait. I've never waited for more than 15 minutes.   The staff there are all on top of their tea-refilling and bussing of the dirty dishes tasks. I never had an empty tea pot or an empty dim sum tin for too long.   The food is awesome and the prices are competitive to the other restaurants on Spring Mountain. Order the pork sui mai, beef rice rolls, egg custard tarts, pork spareribs, and the XLB.   This restaurant had carts that roll around but since the restaurant is so big I always have an anxiety when they get to me, they would run out of the dish I want. Not to be afraid though because I found out that you can ask for specific items and they will get off the cart for you!

TrT7-J-sajDUyw_uBhU8BQ.text: *Thumbs up* They offer that egg custard bun which oozes out warm, neon-orange colored, yolk-flavored sweet custard. Not all dim sum places offer this delectable pastry, which is my favorite.  *Thumbs down* Overall, quality has gone down significantly. The dim sum portions looked smaller and more shriveled up. They were served almost at room temp, and it didn't help that we were seated directly under an AC vent going full blast. Service still takes forever.

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States

UwG0lbc1rwhWEvyDIJtbgg.text: We had a friend's Birthday celebration.  Considering it was a Saturday, it was not busy.  We had a whole spread of dishes.  Lobster, fish (cod was what they recommended since it was fresh), walnut shrimp, roasted duck, Mapo tofu, and a veggie dish (I don't remember the name).  Food was good...I would say the lobster was my favorite.  Service was good as well.  I would consider going back.

YOZBeFqCXtCzybxbxpRn0g.text: Suppose to be the best dim sum in Vegas from what the asian back jack dealers tell me. I came 15 mins after they opened and the service was beyond slow. I mean it was like trying to pull teeth to get anything! You would think service would only be slow when they are slammed busy but I guess not. Food was average dim sum. Nothing really stood out but it did satisfy (somewhat) my craving lol

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Best thing I ordered
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Average

9jTeepiBO9nFb5lb-5zdkw.text: Decent dim sum in what appears to be a real standard Chinese Restaurant but located in a hotel.  Parking was easy and the food was above average.  Service was 3-star at best and the food was 4-star.  Overall 3.5 star. Har Gow (shrimp dumplings) and Sie Mai (pork dumplings) were above average.  Would not order the fried rice, fried noodle or other dishes not in the carts.  Those items were really just ok.

i12S9Ig4YAou85anidXSgg.text: This restaurant is located in the Rio hotel in Vegas. My family and I were craving DimSum and my parents knew of this one from previous travels. We came in just as they opened at 10AM. The service, as with most Chinese restaurants, was fast and clipped without much friendliness.  Due to the earliness, there weren't a ton of carts out yet. We ordered our usuals of dumplings and shumais along with chicken feet, tripe, and pork buns. There were no vegetables out yet, which was a bummer as we were looking forward to some Chinese broccoli.   Overall, the food was not as I would've expected. Dim Sum back in Virginia was definitely better than the dim sum here. I think I would only go back for cravings but otherwise it's not something that needs to be checked off on your travels through the hotels.

m7HUm8i4XTttFKeg4-HemQ.text: You ever have the problem of finding nothing but oil filled dim sum? I did until I was introduced to this magical place.  I grew up on dim sum as a kid, so you could say I'm a connoisseur of the sort. Not only does this place have the classic dishes (i.e. shumai, spare ribs, etc.) but they offer a variety of dumplings I've never come across.  Items to try: 1] steamed scallop & mushroom dumplings 2] panfried pork, mushroom & spinach mini pancake looking things 3] steamed veggie dumplings  Have at it at this place! I know I always do.

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. WOOO WEEE!!

qRkmXThniBwZizCoOuW2_A.text: Yay for Dim Sum! We were pretty excited. Both myself and my friend were on the hunt for good Dim Sum, having eaten it in SF and NYC. So, after asking for suggestions, I decided it was time to give KJ a whirl.  We were seated immediately and offered beverages (water and hot tea). The carts were slow to visit our table, but it was forgiven after I finally got some food in my belly. It was a bit difficult to understand the employees describing items, but fortunately I knew what I wanted. It did create an issue when I asked questions or requested specific items and I received the wrong information or wrong items. I asked three times if the cart had TURNIP Cake and I was given Taro Cake without realizing it. I asked for Shrimp Shumai, but I was given Shrimp Ha Gao. I asked for Char Siu Bao and I got a confused look. It felt like they weren't even listening or attempting.  Anyway, we really enjoyed the Char Siu Bao, Shanghai Dumplings, Shrimp Ha Gao, Fried Shrimp Wanton, Turnip Cake, Beef Rice Noodle, Chow Mein, and Baked Salty Egg Yolk Cream Bun. They were all SO, SO delicious. Extremely filling, but I could've just kept eating.  The prices are wonderful as well and just such a fun atmosphere. I love small plates type of eating, no matter the cuisine. Yum! I would highly recommend the dishes above and go with at least three people since most of the plates have 3-4 pieces. Also, you're able to try even more!

xnxL4EV92rnOoY7YveZc3Q.text: Gourmet dim sum from 11-3.  Variety of delicious small plates.  Gr8 ambiance.  Park on Valley View side of Rio.  Service is good  and prices are are reasonable for a  Resort hotel.  Try the beef stomach, egg sweet buns, roast duck and pork ribs.  Other food is good also.  Flower tea is delicious.

SCXN1g25eEdRK3Qu9pxmyA.text: For average, over-priced, Americanized Chinese food, go here. This will be the stuff of your wildest dreams.  We went on a Monday night and it was relatively not crowded, compared to the amount of patrons on the casino floor and people waiting to check into the hotel. Service was fast and pleasant, though we got some strange looks coming with all our climbing gear. We were too hungry and lazy to wait in the 30 person deep line to check into the Rio.  Everything tasted a little bland, from the hot and sour soup to the honey walnut shrimp to the sweet and sour chicken. The shrimp and chicken were a little soggy. All our food came out really quickly though, so that was a plus.  In the words of my boyfriend, "We should have just gone to Panda Express."

lRaalDHGAIMqtWAayz1eRQ.text: You know what, it's decent Dim Sum.  It'd actually be the best Dim Sum place in all of San Diego if this place existed in San Diego (that says more about how crappy san diego dimsum is though).   Had all the standards..  XLB, cha siu bao, shrimp har gow, siu mai, etc.   They had a decent juk as well.    Overall not too bad.    I wish I could recalibrate all my ratings, but honestly, this place was ok. This is probably a 4 to me by San Diego standards (even though this is vegas... this is definitely a 3 star place by LA standards)

5AWRxNW-FHrxLci1Gwryrg.text: Located across from the Carnival World Buffet inside the Rio Hotel, excellent decor and upper quality food.  I really enjoyed the large shrimp wrapped in the rice noodle (fuun).  Pork ribs, tripe, chicken feet, all really good.

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beautiful decor

HlicuxPtIo-iCdYKncYqzw.text: Came here tonight for a light dinner before the show. Ordered pot stickers, some seafood chow mein and something I never saw before, lobster egg rolls. Pot stickers and chow mein was just OK. We pretty much finished the first two dishes. Lobster egg roll never came. Finally waiter comes and tells us he would check on the egg roll. Came back a few minutes later and tells me I should just cancel the lobster egg roll because the cook doesn't want to make it. He's too busy with a four table banquet dinner to bother with us. WTF!! Get this! There is only 6 other people, us included, besides that four table banquet. It usually is not in my nature to complain. But, this pissed me off. I went and talked to the manager. Informed him what the waiter told us. Asked him is this normal business practice to have the cook refuse to make a dish because he doesn't feel like it! As I finished paying the bill, no tip, they come out and tell me the cook is making my egg roll now. Are you kidding me. I told them they can eat it themselves and left. Not coming back.

8furQoJSeqZKedwzQL-xiA.text: Food is not good. Too much flavor in the dim sum. If you want to try some dim sum, don't go this place!! Cross the street, Ping Pang Pong is 100% much better than this.  For the service, two of the female server kept talking right next to our table when we are eating. Feel really bad.

KTfWo85PI6wEK-ekzbR7vg.text: We waited about 45 minutes on a Sunday afternoon to get seated.  I think we had such a large group that the wait time was much longer.  We had 12 in our party.  I enjoyed most of the food here.  We mainly got dim sum but my cousin wanted noodles so she ordered that in the beginning.    Service was slow but then it was really busy on a Sunday.  I enjoyed all the dim sum but I noticed that when the carts were coming around our table, they were offering the same foods to us, like there was no variety.   The noodles that my cousin ordered came at the very end, when we were paying for the bill.  And the noodles weren't anything special.  Reminded me of Pick up Stix or Panda Express noodles.  I also noticed when walking out, the ladies w/the cart had different items that were not offered while we dined.  Sucks because I didn't have a variety.  I have been to 2 dim sum spots in Vegas.  This place and Ping Pang Pong and my experience at Ping Pang Pong was better.  Sorry KJ...

GjADbzQ7lZQrw5Ss01tItA.text: Great food, but lousy service. The place is really casual, don't have high expectations. Menu is pretty good and taste great. The biggest problem are the servers which barely understand English. Have to tell them several time what you want and they still messing up.

5D96ghfe5fWdBxq3aq-hKw.text: We came here for dinner and I was honestly very disappointed with the food. We got the orange chicken, the hot and sour soup, the tofu in brown sauce and shrimp fried noodles. The portions of everything except for the noodles were tiny. Everything tasted very okay and was nothing special, but was so expensive. Our waiter also asked us in the beginning if we wanted anything to drink and we said water. He asked us if we wanted tea too and we said sure! (Asian restaurants almost always give tea for free unless otherwise specified) They ended up charging us for a pot of tea without saying anything. When we told them about it, they said they would remove it, but it felt pretty sneaky that they didn't say anything about it costing money when they specifically asked us if we wanted it. Overall, was not a fan of this restaurant at all as I've been to so many great Asian places.

YDzEYgBVf1o2PenzT48gKA.text: Me and my cousin went out exploring new dim sum restaurants we haven't tried in Las Vegas. Since I love the first KJ Kitchen location on Spring Mountain and Jones, we decided to try the second location. So far, I love my other dim sum restaurant than KJ and here are the reasons why.  First of all, we came in on Wednesday, September 13 , 2017 around 10:30 a.m. We were greeted and seated. There wasn't a lot of people in the dining room until 11:30 a.m. Instead of drinking random drinks, we drinked traditional with our dim sum, hot tea.  We ordered: - Har Gow - Chicken Feet - Shu Mai - Lo Mai Gai (Sticky rice with meat and egg) - Char Siu Bao (Steamed BBQ Bun) - Shrimp Rice Noodle Roll  We had to wait about 20 more minutes for more different dim sum food to come out. We also ordered: - Char Siu Bao (Baked BBQ Bun) - Coconut Bun - Egg tart - Fried Dumpling - Fried Spinach Dumpling  Some of the foods were ok. The variety was small and not as big. Each dish costs over $2.99 each! The service was alright, I was happy that they served us but not in a happy way. I recommend to go somewhere else to eat dim sum. Other dim sum restaurants probably charge less for each dish and way bigger portion than KJ in the Rio.

YqKM10jAGhq-4JB41loAGw.text: A bit off the beaten path being that it's located at the Rio. So if you're staying on the Strip and don't have a car, Uber or Lyft are your best options to get here.   It's located right next to the Rio buffet. I think KJ took over where the bowling alley used to be. Once you're inside, it's pretty spacious and doesn't seem like you're dining inside of a freaking casino. There are ladies pushing carts of dim sum around, which to me, adds a bit of authenticity to it.  The food itself was alright. However. I thought the food was a bit salty for my liking though, but it was good given how hungry I was. The dim sum food itself was authentic enough and it wasn't added with some fusion mix to it like a lot of the other Chinese restaurants on the strip do.  I haven't had dim sum in Vegas before so I can't really compare it to any other place, but I would definitely come back if I'm ever in Vegas again and am craving for some dim sum. The prices were very reasonable, so that's another plus.

czcA9ag2J6j1fdvhXzIWww.text: Not only does the Rio have great Buffet (i don't really like buffets) but i just found out they have a really great dim sum restaurant as a low cost here at KJ Dim Sum & Seafood. The dim sum here you order by selecting dishes from carts that are continuously pushed around the restaurant and they have a wide variety of options as you would expect at a regular dim sum joint in your area except special orders as their kitchen doesn't open until 11am.  All the dishes we got tasted fresh and was really well done except the shanghai soup dumpling as it was a bit cold. If you want good inexpensive dim sum near the strip i suggest coming here.

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dim sum
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Porridge in the morning. Their dimsum is really good

SOGMRfhMyk5NnkwmhnSk7A.text: After we discovered that Pho Da Nang was straight-up lying about their "vegetarian options," we decided to take a look at these guys instead. Their menu had some listings for Dim Sum and Vegetable items, but we should have walked away when we noticed that TWO of those items had meat listed with them (one featured oysters, the other listed pork. Last time I looked at a 'Food Pyramid,' neither of those met the qualification for being classified as vegetables.)  But we had both been driving all day, so we figured that we could order some dishes we'd had elsewhere before: I ordered szechuan bean curd and my husband ordered deep fried bean curd, Chinese restaurants around the country feature these dishes so it should be pretty standard, right?   So who's brilliant fucking idea was it to stuff SHRIMP into a VEGETARIAN DISH without telling a paying customer? If it was one chunk that happened to land on the plate by accident, then I could understand that. But that's not what happened, there was shrimp stuffed dead-center inside every single block of fried bean curd on his plate. Every. Single. ONE. When I saw and smelled the shrimp in his food, I stopped eating mine immediately.  We reported this place to the management at Rio.

vjkTfPWxSpObtlPqB7NXJw.text: Great authentic Dim Sum.  Amazing prices.  Fantastic service.  Very sweet people and yummy food!!!

EcoqWhZfe-xv9uaGQ842Rg.text: We entered the extravagant restaurant to an empty hostess stand. The hostess came in wearing a thick jacket and we were seated by a hesitant waitress. When we sat down the hostess only asked one of us our drink orders and was gone. The food was decent but the prices are outrageous. The scallops are nickel size, the kind out of a bag, but the price for it left a bad taste. When we asked for recommendations the hostess said the price of the overpriced seafood and then said they were out. Needless to say, it was not a good experience and the service needed some training. The food is comparable to panda express

EHUwTjJG4QrFdTFENPT9kw.text: Our experience here was pleasant. Kind of like any other experience you would have at a Chinese restaurant but a little fancier.   Something to note, they stop serving dim sum at 2pm but have a few items ala carte.   We ordered a few of our favorites: Haianese chicken, pea sprout leaves w garlic sauce, beef w orange peel and salt and pepper fried fish filet. They were all pretty delicious and generous family style portions. There really wasnt anything to complain about.  One thing was the orange beef could have been crispier, some people like it soft and tender and other people like light batter and crispy.   We got a complimentary dessert which looked like sweet potato soup, wasn't a big fan but it was a nice thought.   Will definitely come back again. Hopefully in time for dim sum!

ZaeX8fpPr07vKGwOHCQ3Wg.text: I guess these is real Chinese food.  We had eight people and nobody cared for it.  The food is very bland. The tea has the ground up leaves still in it . The fish was over cooked. Very expensive place. I'll not go back. It is a cross from the buffet in the Rio,so the buffet is a better value.

SWwYGlE61H-N4GjW9lZDBg.text: We ate here on our way to the Penn & Teller show.  We seemed to beat the crowds waiting in line for the buffet.  We think we got the better end of the deal, as our food was fresh, fast, and satisfying. They can handle ADA accommodations and large groups. After we got seated, several large families came in after a marathon, and their staff handled them like champs. We had a hard time deciding what to get, but we recommend their scallop dishes over everything!  A little on the pricier side for dinner, but it IS Vegas and this is inside a hotel, so it was on par with what we were expecting.  I still want to come back or a brunch Dim Sum.  Next trip.

zU6D0QkdeuoJvTRFJ6RD9A.text: Came here for the day after the wedding dim sum. They had the usual fare like siomai, har gaw, cha sio pao, fong tsao and lo mai Kai. Also had many shrimp-filled options.   Everything tasted very fresh! The best part was the egg custard tart (dan tat) was fresh right out of the oven and was piping hot.  Truly enjoyed the meal and would recommend their food!

R-SMJvhwkUNlLSydbToITA.text: Good food and price was good. It was crazy though that the moment we sat down we were just overwhelmed with the dim sum carts. Didn't even have a chance to order drinks yet and carts were coming from every direction almost all at once. It was pretty dead that time so maybe that's why. All in all good and price was good.

QUCQnHnMRFfbPL_YSrgJAw.text: Nestled inside Rio casino, is a dim sum restaurant. Go figure, only in Vegas. We arrived a bit early, but it was a short wait until they opened the doors. The carts were already flowing so we were hopeful. Service was slow at first, no one brought us water or tended to us besides the cart ladies. We had to flag down a server who looked less than please to serve us. After that little hitch, it was fine. They have your typical assortment...congee, chicken feet, shumai, dumplings, pork ribs...they were all pretty good. What was disappointing was they didn't have anything else ready..not even rice! We couldn't even order anything from the menu. Don't make the mistake of being hangry and going as early as we did.

photos.caption: Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dim sum assortment
Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Congee

Ik_ymn89O-67HP79xUtEuA.text: After learning KJ's offers dim sum during the lunch hour, my parents and I decided to give them a try. And we are so glad we did so! The food was plentiful and delicious. At times, we didn't know what was being offered, but our server was a very good guide. My favorite was the sweet BBQ steamed buns and the fried rice. Honestly though, it was all good. And at a tremendously low price! We enjoyed ourselves so much that we came twice during our stay.

ArhBqHrsyGRTMJlo0oTlRw.text: SUMMARY: Apparently this is a popular spot for dim-sum; my NON-dim-sum experience was pretty underwhelming.  THE UGLY DETAILS: I am passing away my morning at The Rio, while an auto shop across the street is installing new seating leather in my car. It's a Thursday at 11:30am. This venue has about 70 table-tops. And, except for a couple of the 12-tops, this place is full to the brim. Almost entirely with Asians. And I mean local Asians, not tourists. And they are all here for the dim-sum carts. When they could have gone just two blocks over into Chinatown for their dim-sum. To me, that speaks volumes regarding the quality of the dim-sum here.  I was seated promptly, to an egg-white tablecloth 2-top. One paper napkin and some plastic chops are my only table-mates, no salt, pepper, soy or rooster. I will be truly be dining alone. The entire staff, not surprisingly, were also Asian. My servers had accents so thick, I could only understand a word here and there, and they chattered away at the speed-of-light. Hence the direction that my meal was actually taking evolved into a bit of a mystery.  Again, I was only one of two tables that was not entirely Asian. The other was four WSOPers who were already drunk. Meaning they were already eliminated from the tournament in the early rounds. Yet they were taking turns trying to verbally out-blab one another with their insightful poker observations of the other players. General Custer graduated last-place in his competition at West Point - but he also got eliminated first at the Little Big Horn. All of you lost. Babble on about how THAT played out. And drop the testosterone talk. Then maybe you'll be better poker players down the road.  The menu is over-priced, again not entirely a surprise given this is inside a casino property. The cheapest meals on the menu were Mongolian Beef or Kung Pao Chicken, $17 a plate. A bowl of Wonton soup, get this, $15. Maybe it was a bowl the size of Viet pho, but so what? It's still step-sis to chicken noodle soup. Most of the plates were in the $20s, $30s. $40s for duck. I went with the Kung Pao. And two egg rolls at $9.  "No egg rolls. Spring rolls." Ok, so it's spring rolls. Rapid-fire unintelligible chatter. I think he's telling me that's going to be $10. Or maybe $10 MORE. I can't tell. I ask if the Kung Pao comes with fried rice. More rapid-fire unintelligible chatter. I think the answer is yes, for $1 more. "Fry rice what?" I say pork. The menu doesn't have a single beverage listed on it, not even hot tea, so I figured those prices were stealth so as to be outrageous - and stuck with water.  The spring rolls appear in under two minutes. Fried not fresh, three of them. They are warm outside, cold inside. That means they got nuked to find their half-life on my table. Meh.  Then the Kung Pao. With a side of white rice. I say I thought I got ordered the fried rice. More rapid-fire unintelligible chatter. I think now he is jotting down a full order of fried rice which is going to come in at nearly $20. I signal to stop, saying I will just eat what I have.  When he leaves, I see him go consult with his peers, all looking back at my table, apparently discussing my unusual ordering habits. What with me wanting egg rolls and a side of fried rice in a Chinese restaurant and all. Instead of eating conger eel and whatever off the carts.  The Kung Pao is bland. Really bland. It's no more tasty than what I can get round the corner at my local take-out joint. If that tasty. Not bad, just bland. The portion is what I would call a bit less than average. Now I am thinking it's a durn good thing I didn't go with dim sum, because I would have had no idea what any item was going to cost ... and so I could have easily ended up with some kind of three-digit tab for lunch.  When I got back out into the casino, I was still hungry. And I mean immediately, not in an hour. I caught myself wishing I had tried a Philly Steak at the Sports Book instead.  RECOMMENDATION: All these Asian customers are probably not wrong, so the dim-sum is probably pretty good. I mean it all even looked good. So if you are down for dim, it's likely worth investing in your own evaluation. But for non-dim sum, steer clear and just head up the street to Chinatown.

mJWDG8EaP2uHWz8gngZIhA.text: I'm giving one star bc, even though they have dim sum in their name, it's only available at lunch. This was told to us by a slightly rude lady at the reception desk of the restaurant tonight. I assume it's True.

QWGG58y5szFza52lM6OVDA.text: Food here is excellent, very reasonable prices, and great selection of dim sum.  Food - 4.5/5 Atmosphere - 2/5 Value - 4/5 Service - 4/5  This visit I tried the: congee with 1000 year egg and pork Chicken feet Kai lan with oyster sauce zongzi with egg, lap cheong, shiitake Coconut bun Taro bun Pork bun Shumai Har gow Oolong tea  All of which was excellent.

wYZokX-tyoNBik9fjyDsyA.text: Very good Dim Sum. Great selection attentive service good prices. Very popular among the Asian crowd which is a good sign I think. Our kids loved it awesome place

L6-rkgDTwP5fq728Q8X1rA.text: Breakfast plans on the Strip fell through today, and my awesome plan B was to take my mom to one of Henderson's new brunch hotspots. I wish that I'd stuck to that instead of making an impromptu detour to try out this nearby restaurant.  KJ Dim Sum & Seafood is conveniently located near the Valley View entrance of the Rio. Just park outside (assuming that's allowed/available) or in the "Carnival" parking garage and it's a quick walk that won't even take you by any slot machines.  Today was the Monday following Easter weekend, and peak lunch was exceedingly busy. I would guess that the vast majority of their clientele today was Chinese tourists. We had a roughly 20-minute wait for a table for two (important: keep the "raffle" ticket which the host gives to you). After we were seated, we received a small a la carte menu, which we simply ignored. The dim sum carts arrived promptly.  My favorites today were the cheong fun (rice noodle rolls with shrimp) and the egg tart. The rice noodles were fluffy and the shrimp were cooked perfectly. The sauce complemented the dish just right. Make sure they cut it into smaller pieces for you. The egg tart was one of my last bites, and even though I was full (and bored with the other items), my taste buds were thrilled. The flaky crust and hot egg custard that unexpectedly started to melt on the tongue were fantastic.  The chicken feet were pretty good. I'd order them again. The turnip cake was fine, with a bit of a crisp on the outside and enough seasoning throughout that it might be enjoyed on its own. The har gow (shrimp dumplings) were tasty, but the shell was too easily torn apart, making it hard to fish out of the metal container.  That's about all that I'd reorder from today's choices. The shu mai was disappointingly bland for some reason. The shrimp balls were even worse. They were too hard and something was very off about the interior. Either there was too much flour, or the shrimp was too mushy. It just wasn't the typical juicy shrimp interior, and the mayo sauce should not have been wholly necessary to rescue the shrimp. Finally, I'd have to classify the taro dumplings as another letdown. They were smaller than expected, and not as flavorful. I appreciate that they weren't dripping with oil, but that's not why I eat dim sum.  Prices are were $2.28-$3.98 per dish, and $1.00 per person for hot jasmine tea. Service was surprisingly decent, with quick responses to such concerns as lack of soy and XO sauces on the table, requests for a to-go box, and closing the check. All of these were positives, but not enough to outweigh the boredom of the majority of the meal.  KJ Dim Sum just didn't live up to their reputation. This would be a 7/10 if I could rate it that way. I don't get decimals in this 5-star scale, and the disappointments today outweighed the few positives, so I'm saddened but content to round it down. I'd easily stop by again to ask for egg tarts and possibly cheong fun to-go, and that's about it.

w0zchmUFG79Qh83cajhreQ.text: Items selected: Egg Custard Duck Crispy Shrimp Coconut Puffs Shrimp Balls Baked Salty Egg Yolk Cream Bun  Taro Puffs Century Egg and Seaweed Congee BBQ Pork Buns Steamed Egg Yolk Buns  Most certainly not a connoisseur of dim sum but having now visited a handful of the reported 'best' in North America from Toronto to Vancouver/Richmond and down to the San Gabriel Valley it was with high hopes that I entered KJ Dim Sum at The Rio alongside a friend and with the restaurant packed to overflowing with Asians both local and visiting the carts and service that awaited rendered an admirable effort the sorts of which many would have you believe cannot be found in Las Vegas.  Admittedly a 'standardized' menu featuring solid renditions of the classics but little innovation it would be easy for me to dock points for issues such as tepid duck or small, slightly overcooked shrimp but taking into account the nature of cart service compared to the menu style common to the elite of the SGV or BC nearly every dish we selected was nicely prepared and ample in portion, the total bill for 11 selections ringing in at $45 before tax and tip.  Speaking to specific must orders, particular favorites particularly well done would include both the baked salty egg yolk buns and the even more impressive steamed version of the same, but most of all the golf-ball sized crispy shrimp balls served along semi-sweet Chinese mayo sauce - the rich, supple interior so good a second order for 'dessert' proved mandatory.

Photo of KJ Dim Sum & Seafood - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Coconut Buns
